text_entry: Of my cousin Vernons are not yet come up:

speaker: VERNON
text_entry: Your uncle Worcesters horse came but today;

speaker: VERNON
text_entry: And now their pride and mettle is asleep,

speaker: VERNON
text_entry: Their courage with hard labour tame and dull,

speaker: VERNON
text_entry: That not a horse is half the half of himself.

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: So are the horses of the enemy

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: In general, journey-bated and brought low:

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: The better part of ours are full of rest.

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: The number of the king exceedeth ours:

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: For Gods sake. cousin, stay till all come in.

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: The trumpet sounds a parley

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: Enter SIR WALTER BLUNT

speaker: SIR WALTER BLUNT
text_entry: I come with gracious offers from the king,

speaker: SIR WALTER BLUNT
text_entry: if you vouchsafe me hearing and respect.

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Welcome, Sir Walter Blunt; and would to God

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: You were of our determination!

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Some of us love you well; and even those some

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Envy your great deservings and good name,

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Because you are not of our quality,

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: But stand against us like an enemy.

speaker: SIR WALTER BLUNT
text_entry: And God defend but still I should stand so,

speaker: SIR WALTER BLUNT
text_entry: So long as out of limit and true rule

speaker: SIR WALTER BLUNT
text_entry: You stand against anointed majesty.

speaker: SIR WALTER BLUNT
text_entry: But to my charge. The king hath sent to know

speaker: SIR WALTER BLUNT
text_entry: The nature of your griefs, and whereupon

speaker: SIR WALTER BLUNT
text_entry: You conjure from the breast of civil peace

speaker: SIR WALTER BLUNT
text_entry: Such bold hostility, teaching his duteous land

speaker: SIR WALTER BLUNT
text_entry: Audacious cruelty. If that the king

speaker: SIR WALTER BLUNT
text_entry: Have any way your good deserts forgot,

speaker: SIR WALTER BLUNT
text_entry: Which he confesseth to be manifold,

speaker: SIR WALTER BLUNT
text_entry: He bids you name your griefs; and with all speed

speaker: SIR WALTER BLUNT
text_entry: You shall have your desires with interest

speaker: SIR WALTER BLUNT
text_entry: And pardon absolute for yourself and these

speaker: SIR WALTER BLUNT
text_entry: Herein misled by your suggestion.

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: The king is kind; and well we know the king

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Knows at what time to promise, when to pay.

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: My father and my uncle and myself

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Did give him that same royalty he wears;

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: And when he was not six and twenty strong,

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Sick in the worlds regard, wretched and low,

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: A poor unminded outlaw sneaking home,

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: My father gave him welcome to the shore;

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: And when he heard him swear and vow to God

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: He came but to be Duke of Lancaster,

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: To sue his livery and beg his peace,

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: With tears of innocency and terms of zeal,

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: My father, in kind heart and pity moved,

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Swore him assistance and performd it too.

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Now when the lords and barons of the realm

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Perceived Northumberland did lean to him,

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: The more and less came in with cap and knee;

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Met him in boroughs, cities, villages,

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Attended him on bridges, stood in lanes,

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Laid gifts before him, profferd him their oaths,

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Gave him their heirs, as pages followd him

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Even at the heels in golden multitudes.

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: He presently, as greatness knows itself,

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Steps me a little higher than his vow

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Made to my father, while his blood was poor,

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Upon the naked shore at Ravenspurgh;

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: And now, forsooth, takes on him to reform

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Some certain edicts and some strait decrees

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: That lie too heavy on the commonwealth,

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Cries out upon abuses, seems to weep

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Over his countrys wrongs; and by this face,

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: This seeming brow of justice, did he win

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: The hearts of all that he did angle for;

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Proceeded further; cut me off the heads

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Of all the favourites that the absent king

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: In deputation left behind him here,

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: When he was personal in the Irish war.

speaker: SIR WALTER BLUNT
text_entry: Tut, I came not to hear this.

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Then to the point.

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: In short time after, he deposed the king;

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Soon after that, deprived him of his life;

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: And in the neck of that, taskd the whole state:

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: To make that worse, sufferd his kinsman March,

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Who is, if every owner were well placed,

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Indeed his king, to be engaged in Wales,

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: There without ransom to lie forfeited;

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Disgraced me in my happy victories,

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Sought to entrap me by intelligence;

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Rated mine uncle from the council-board;

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: In rage dismissd my father from the court;

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Broke oath on oath, committed wrong on wrong,

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: And in conclusion drove us to seek out

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: This head of safety; and withal to pry

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Into his title, the which we find

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Too indirect for long continuance.

speaker: SIR WALTER BLUNT
text_entry: Shall I return this answer to the king?

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Not so, Sir Walter: well withdraw awhile.

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Go to the king; and let there be impawnd

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Some surety for a safe return again,

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: And in the morning early shall my uncle

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Bring him our purposes: and so farewell.

speaker: SIR WALTER BLUNT
text_entry: I would you would accept of grace and love.

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: And may be so we shall.

speaker: SIR WALTER BLUNT
text_entry: Pray God you do.

speaker: SIR WALTER BLUNT
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: SIR WALTER BLUNT
text_entry: SCENE IV. York. The ARCHBISHOPS palace.

speaker: SIR WALTER BLUNT
text_entry: Enter the ARCHBISHOP OF YORK and SIR MICHAEL

speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK
text_entry: Hie, good Sir Michael; bear this sealed brief

speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK
text_entry: With winged haste to the lord marshal;

speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK
text_entry: This to my cousin Scroop, and all the rest

speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK
text_entry: To whom they are directed. If you knew

speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK
text_entry: How much they do to import, you would make haste.

speaker: SIR MICHAEL
text_entry: My good lord,

speaker: SIR MICHAEL
text_entry: I guess their tenor.

speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK
text_entry: Like enough you do.

speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK
text_entry: To-morrow, good Sir Michael, is a day

speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK
text_entry: Wherein the fortune of ten thousand men

speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK
text_entry: Must bide the touch; for, sir, at Shrewsbury,

speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK
text_entry: As I am truly given to understand,

speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK
text_entry: The king with mighty and quick-raised power

speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK
text_entry: Meets with Lord Harry: and, I fear, Sir Michael,

speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK
text_entry: What with the sickness of Northumberland,

speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK
text_entry: Whose power was in the first proportion,

speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK
text_entry: And what with Owen Glendowers absence thence,

speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK
text_entry: Who with them was a rated sinew too

speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK
text_entry: And comes not in, oer-ruled by prophecies,

speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK
text_entry: I fear the power of Percy is too weak

speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK
text_entry: To wage an instant trial with the king.

speaker: SIR MICHAEL
text_entry: Why, my good lord, you need not fear;

speaker: SIR MICHAEL
text_entry: There is Douglas and Lord Mortimer.

speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK
text_entry: No, Mortimer is not there.

speaker: SIR MICHAEL
text_entry: But there is Mordake, Vernon, Lord Harry Percy,

speaker: SIR MICHAEL
text_entry: And there is my Lord of Worcester and a head

speaker: SIR MICHAEL
text_entry: Of gallant warriors, noble gentlemen.

speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK
text_entry: And so there is: but yet the king hath drawn

speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK
text_entry: The special head of all the land together:

speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK
text_entry: The Prince of Wales, Lord John of Lancaster,

speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK
text_entry: The noble Westmoreland and warlike Blunt;

speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK
text_entry: And moe corrivals and dear men

speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK
text_entry: Of estimation and command in arms.

speaker: SIR MICHAEL
text_entry: Doubt not, my lord, they shall be well opposed.

speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK
text_entry: I hope no less, yet needful tis to fear;

speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK
text_entry: And, to prevent the worst, Sir Michael, speed:

speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK
text_entry: For if Lord Percy thrive not, ere the king

speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK
text_entry: Dismiss his power, he means to visit us,

speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK
text_entry: For he hath heard of our confederacy,

speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK
text_entry: And tis but wisdom to make strong against him:

speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK
text_entry: Therefore make haste. I must go write again

speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK
text_entry: To other friends; and so farewell, Sir Michael.

speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK
text_entry: ACT V

speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK
text_entry: SCENE I. KING HENRY IVs camp near Shrewsbury.

speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK
text_entry: Enter KING HENRY, PRINCE HENRY, Lord John of  LANCASTER, EARL OF WESTMORELAND, SIR WALTER BLUNT, and FALSTAFF

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: How bloodily the sun begins to peer

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: Above yon busky hill! the day looks pale

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: At his distemperature.

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: The southern wind

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: Doth play the trumpet to his purposes,

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: And by his hollow whistling in the leaves

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: Foretells a tempest and a blustering day.

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: Then with the losers let it sympathize,

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: For nothing can seem foul to those that win.

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: The trumpet sounds

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: Enter WORCESTER and VERNON

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: How now, my Lord of Worcester! tis not well

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: That you and I should meet upon such terms

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: As now we meet. You have deceived our trust,

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: And made us doff our easy robes of peace,

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: To crush our old limbs in ungentle steel:

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: This is not well, my lord, this is not well.

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: What say you to it? will you again unknit

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: This curlish knot of all-abhorred war?

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: And move in that obedient orb again

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: Where you did give a fair and natural light,

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: And be no more an exhaled meteor,

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: A prodigy of fear and a portent

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: Of broached mischief to the unborn times?

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: Hear me, my liege:

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: For mine own part, I could be well content

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: To entertain the lag-end of my life

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: With quiet hours; for I do protest,

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: I have not sought the day of this dislike.

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: You have not sought it! how comes it, then?

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: Rebellion lay in his way, and he found it.

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: Peace, chewet, peace!

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: It pleased your majesty to turn your looks

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: Of favour from myself and all our house;

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: And yet I must remember you, my lord,

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: We were the first and dearest of your friends.

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: For you my staff of office did I break

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: In Richards time; and posted day and night

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: to meet you on the way, and kiss your hand,

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: When yet you were in place and in account

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: Nothing so strong and fortunate as I.

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: It was myself, my brother and his son,

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: That brought you home and boldly did outdare

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: The dangers of the time. You swore to us,

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: And you did swear that oath at Doncaster,

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: That you did nothing purpose gainst the state;

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: Nor claim no further than your new-falln right,

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: The seat of Gaunt, dukedom of Lancaster:

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: To this we swore our aid. But in short space

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: It raind down fortune showering on your head;

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: And such a flood of greatness fell on you,

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: What with our help, what with the absent king,

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: What with the injuries of a wanton time,

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: The seeming sufferances that you had borne,

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: And the contrarious winds that held the king

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: So long in his unlucky Irish wars

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: That all in England did repute him dead:

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: And from this swarm of fair advantages

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: You took occasion to be quickly wood

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: To gripe the general sway into your hand;

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: Forget your oath to us at Doncaster;

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: And being fed by us you used us so

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: As that ungentle hull, the cuckoos bird,

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: Useth the sparrow; did oppress our nest;

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: Grew by our feeding to so great a bulk

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: That even our love durst not come near your sight

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: For fear of swallowing; but with nimble wing

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: We were enforced, for safety sake, to fly

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: Out of sight and raise this present head;

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: Whereby we stand opposed by such means

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: As you yourself have forged against yourself

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: By unkind usage, dangerous countenance,

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: And violation of all faith and troth

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: Sworn to us in your younger enterprise.

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: These things indeed you have articulate,

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: Proclaimd at market-crosses, read in churches,

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: To face the garment of rebellion

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: With some fine colour that may please the eye

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: Of fickle changelings and poor discontents,

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: Which gape and rub the elbow at the news

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: Of hurlyburly innovation:

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: And never yet did insurrection want

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: Such water-colours to impaint his cause;

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: Nor moody beggars, starving for a time

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: Of pellmell havoc and confusion.

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: In both your armies there is many a soul

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: Shall pay full dearly for this encounter,

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: If once they join in trial. Tell your nephew,

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: The Prince of Wales doth join with all the world

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: In praise of Henry Percy: by my hopes,

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: This present enterprise set off his head,

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: I do not think a braver gentleman,

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: More active-valiant or more valiant-young,

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: More daring or more bold, is now alive

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: To grace this latter age with noble deeds.

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: For my part, I may speak it to my shame,

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: I have a truant been to chivalry;

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: And so I hear he doth account me too;

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: Yet this before my fathers majesty--

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: I am content that he shall take the odds

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: Of his great name and estimation,

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: And will, to save the blood on either side,

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: Try fortune with him in a single fight.

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: And, Prince of Wales, so dare we venture thee,

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: Albeit considerations infinite

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: Do make against it. No, good Worcester, no,

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: We love our people well; even those we love

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: That are misled upon your cousins part;

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: And, will they take the offer of our grace,

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: Both he and they and you, every man

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: Shall be my friend again and Ill be his:

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: So tell your cousin, and bring me word

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: What he will do: but if he will not yield,

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: Rebuke and dread correction wait on us

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: And they shall do their office. So, be gone;

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: We will not now be troubled with reply:

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: We offer fair; take it advisedly.

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: Exeunt WORCESTER and VERNON

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: It will not be accepted, on my life:

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: The Douglas and the Hotspur both together

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: Are confident against the world in arms.

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: Hence, therefore, every leader to his charge;

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: For, on their answer, will we set on them:

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: And God befriend us, as our cause is just!

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: Exeunt all but PRINCE HENRY and FALSTAFF

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: Hal, if thou see me down in the battle and bestride

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: me, so; tis a point of friendship.

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: Nothing but a colossus can do thee that friendship.

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: Say thy prayers, and farewell.

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: I  would twere bed-time, Hal, and all well.

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: Why, thou owest God a death.

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: Exit PRINCE HENRY

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: Tis not due yet; I would be loath to pay him before

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: his day. What need I be so forward with him that

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: calls not on me? Well, tis no matter; honour pricks

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: me on. Yea, but how if honour prick me off when I

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: come on? how then? Can honour set to a leg? no: or

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: an arm? no: or take away the grief of a wound? no.

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: Honour hath no skill in surgery, then? no. What is

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: honour? a word. What is in that word honour? what

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: is that honour? air. A trim reckoning! Who hath it?

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: he that died o Wednesday. Doth he feel it? no.

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: Doth he hear it? no. Tis insensible, then. Yea,

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: to the dead. But will it not live with the living?

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: no. Why? detraction will not suffer it. Therefore

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: Ill none of it. Honour is a mere scutcheon: and so

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: ends my catechism.

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: Exit

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: SCENE II. The rebel camp.

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: Enter WORCESTER and VERNON

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: O, no, my nephew must not know, Sir Richard,

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: The liberal and kind offer of the king.

speaker: VERNON
text_entry: Twere best he did.

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: Then are we all undone.

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: It is not possible, it cannot be,

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: The king should keep his word in loving us;

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: He will suspect us still and find a time

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: To punish this offence in other faults:

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: Suspicion all our lives shall be stuck full of eyes;

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: For treason is but trusted like the fox,

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: Who, neer so tame, so cherishd and lockd up,

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: Will have a wild trick of his ancestors.

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: Look how we can, or sad or merrily,

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: Interpretation will misquote our looks,

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: And we shall feed like oxen at a stall,

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: The better cherishd, still the nearer death.

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: My nephews trespass may be well forgot;

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: it hath the excuse of youth and heat of blood,

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: And an adopted name of privilege,

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: A hair-braind Hotspur, governd by a spleen:

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: All his offences live upon my head

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: And on his fathers; we did train him on,

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: And, his corruption being taen from us,

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: We, as the spring of all, shall pay for all.

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: Therefore, good cousin, let not Harry know,

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: In any case, the offer of the king.

speaker: VERNON
text_entry: Deliver what you will; Ill say tis so.

speaker: VERNON
text_entry: Here comes your cousin.

speaker: VERNON
text_entry: Enter HOTSPUR and DOUGLAS

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: My uncle is returnd:

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Deliver up my Lord of Westmoreland.

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Uncle, what news?

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: The king will bid you battle presently.

speaker: EARL OF DOUGLAS
text_entry: Defy him by the Lord of Westmoreland.

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Lord Douglas, go you and tell him so.

speaker: EARL OF DOUGLAS
text_entry: Marry, and shall, and very willingly.

speaker: EARL OF DOUGLAS
text_entry: Exit

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: There is no seeming mercy in the king.

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Did you beg any? God forbid!

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: I told him gently of our grievances,

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: Of his oath-breaking; which he mended thus,

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: By now forswearing that he is forsworn:

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: He calls us rebels, traitors; and will scourge

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: With haughty arms this hateful name in us.

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: Re-enter the EARL OF DOUGLAS

speaker: EARL OF DOUGLAS
text_entry: Arm, gentlemen; to arms! for I have thrown

speaker: EARL OF DOUGLAS
text_entry: A brave defiance in King Henrys teeth,

speaker: EARL OF DOUGLAS
text_entry: And Westmoreland, that was engaged, did bear it;

speaker: EARL OF DOUGLAS
text_entry: Which cannot choose but bring him quickly on.

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: The Prince of Wales steppd forth before the king,

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: And, nephew, challenged you to single fight.

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: O, would the quarrel lay upon our heads,

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: And that no man might draw short breath today

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: But I and Harry Monmouth! Tell me, tell me,

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: How showd his tasking? seemd it in contempt?

speaker: VERNON
text_entry: No, by my soul; I never in my life

speaker: VERNON
text_entry: Did hear a challenge urged more modestly,

speaker: VERNON
text_entry: Unless a brother should a brother dare

speaker: VERNON
text_entry: To gentle exercise and proof of arms.

speaker: VERNON
text_entry: He gave you all the duties of a man;

speaker: VERNON
text_entry: Trimmd up your praises with a princely tongue,

speaker: VERNON
text_entry: Spoke to your deservings like a chronicle,

speaker: VERNON
text_entry: Making you ever better than his praise

speaker: VERNON
text_entry: By still dispraising praise valued in you;

speaker: VERNON
text_entry: And, which became him like a prince indeed,

speaker: VERNON
text_entry: He made a blushing cital of himself;

speaker: VERNON
text_entry: And chid his truant youth with such a grace

speaker: VERNON
text_entry: As if he masterd there a double spirit.

speaker: VERNON
text_entry: Of teaching and of learning instantly.

speaker: VERNON
text_entry: There did he pause: but let me tell the world,

speaker: VERNON
text_entry: If he outlive the envy of this day,

speaker: VERNON
text_entry: England did never owe so sweet a hope,

speaker: VERNON
text_entry: So much misconstrued in his wantonness.

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Cousin, I think thou art enamoured

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: On his follies: never did I hear

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Of any prince so wild a libertine.

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: But be he as he will, yet once ere night

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: I will embrace him with a soldiers arm,

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: That he shall shrink under my courtesy.

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Arm, arm with speed: and, fellows, soldiers, friends,

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Better consider what you have to do

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Than I, that have not well the gift of tongue,

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Can lift your blood up with persuasion.

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Enter a Messenger

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: My lord, here are letters for you.

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: I cannot read them now.

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: O gentlemen, the time of life is short!

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: To spend that shortness basely were too long,

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: If life did ride upon a dials point,

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Still ending at the arrival of an hour.

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: An if we live, we live to tread on kings;

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: If die, brave death, when princes die with us!

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Now, for our consciences, the arms are fair,

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: When the intent of bearing them is just.

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Enter another Messenger

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: My lord, prepare; the king comes on apace.

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: I thank him, that he cuts me from my tale,

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: For I profess not talking; only this--

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Let each man do his best: and here draw I

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: A sword, whose temper I intend to stain

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: With the best blood that I can meet withal

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: In the adventure of this perilous day.

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Now, Esperance! Percy! and set on.

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Sound all the lofty instruments of war,

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: And by that music let us all embrace;

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: For, heaven to earth, some of us never shall

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: A second time do such a courtesy.

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: The trumpets sound. They embrace, and exeunt

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: SCENE III. Plain between the camps.

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: KING HENRY enters with his power. Alarum to the battle. Then enter DOUGLAS and SIR WALTER BLUNT

speaker: SIR WALTER BLUNT
text_entry: What is thy name, that in the battle thus

speaker: SIR WALTER BLUNT
text_entry: Thou crossest me? what honour dost thou seek

speaker: SIR WALTER BLUNT
text_entry: Upon my head?

speaker: EARL OF DOUGLAS
text_entry: Know then, my name is Douglas;

speaker: EARL OF DOUGLAS
text_entry: And I do haunt thee in the battle thus

speaker: EARL OF DOUGLAS
text_entry: Because some tell me that thou art a king.

speaker: SIR WALTER BLUNT
text_entry: They tell thee true.

speaker: EARL OF DOUGLAS
text_entry: The Lord of Stafford dear to-day hath bought

speaker: EARL OF DOUGLAS
text_entry: Thy likeness, for instead of thee, King Harry,

speaker: EARL OF DOUGLAS
text_entry: This sword hath ended him: so shall it thee,

speaker: EARL OF DOUGLAS
text_entry: Unless thou yield thee as my prisoner.

speaker: SIR WALTER BLUNT
text_entry: I was not born a yielder, thou proud Scot;

speaker: SIR WALTER BLUNT
text_entry: And thou shalt find a king that will revenge

speaker: SIR WALTER BLUNT
text_entry: Lord Staffords death.

speaker: SIR WALTER BLUNT
text_entry: They fight. DOUGLAS kills SIR WALTER BLUNT. Enter HOTSPUR

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: O Douglas, hadst thou fought at Holmedon thus,

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: never had triumphd upon a Scot.

speaker: EARL OF DOUGLAS
text_entry: Alls done, alls won; here breathless lies the king.

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Where?

speaker: EARL OF DOUGLAS
text_entry: Here.

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: This, Douglas? no: I know this face full well:

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: A gallant knight he was, his name was Blunt;

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Semblably furnishd like the king himself.

speaker: EARL OF DOUGLAS
text_entry: A fool go with thy soul, whither it goes!

speaker: EARL OF DOUGLAS
text_entry: A borrowd title hast thou bought too dear:

speaker: EARL OF DOUGLAS
text_entry: Why didst thou tell me that thou wert a king?

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: The king hath many marching in his coats.

speaker: EARL OF DOUGLAS
text_entry: Now, by my sword, I will kill all his coats;

speaker: EARL OF DOUGLAS
text_entry: Ill murder all his wardrobe, piece by piece,

speaker: EARL OF DOUGLAS
text_entry: Until I meet the king.

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Up, and away!

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Our soldiers stand full fairly for the day.

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Alarum. Enter FALSTAFF, solus

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: Though I could scape shot-free at London, I fear

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: the shot here; heres no scoring but upon the pate.

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: Soft! who are you? Sir Walter Blunt: theres honour

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: for you! heres no vanity! I am as hot as moulten

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: lead, and as heavy too: God keep lead out of me! I

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: need no more weight than mine own bowels. I have

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: led my ragamuffins where they are peppered: theres

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: not three of my hundred and fifty left alive; and

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: they are for the towns end, to beg during life.

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: But who comes here?

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: Enter PRINCE HENRY

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: What, standst thou idle here? lend me thy sword:

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: Many a nobleman lies stark and stiff

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: Under the hoofs of vaunting enemies,

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: Whose deaths are yet unrevenged: I prithee,

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: lend me thy sword.

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: O Hal, I prithee, give me leave to breathe awhile.

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: Turk Gregory never did such deeds in arms as I have

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: done this day. I have paid Percy, I have made him sure.

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: He is, indeed; and living to kill thee. I prithee,

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: lend me thy sword.

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: Nay, before God, Hal, if Percy be alive, thou getst

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: not my sword; but take my pistol, if thou wilt.

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: Give it to me: what, is it in the case?

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: Ay, Hal; tis hot, tis hot; theres that will sack a city.

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: PRINCE HENRY draws it out, and finds it to be a bottle of sack

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: What, is it a time to jest and dally now?

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: He throws the bottle at him. Exit

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: Well, if Percy be alive, Ill pierce him. If he do

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: come in my way, so: if he do not, if I come in his

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: willingly, let him make a carbonado of me. I like

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: not such grinning honour as Sir Walter hath: give me

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: life: which if I can save, so; if not, honour comes

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: unlooked for, and theres an end.

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: Exit FALSTAFF

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: SCENE IV. Another part of the field.

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: Alarum. Excursions. Enter PRINCE HENRY, LORD JOHN OF LANCASTER, and EARL OF WESTMORELAND

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: I prithee,

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: Harry, withdraw thyself; thou bleedst too much.

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: Lord John of Lancaster, go you with him.

speaker: LANCASTER
text_entry: Not I, my lord, unless I did bleed too.

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: I beseech your majesty, make up,

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: Lest your retirement do amaze your friends.

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: I will do so.

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: My Lord of Westmoreland, lead him to his tent.

speaker: WESTMORELAND
text_entry: Come, my lord, Ill lead you to your tent.

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: Lead me, my lord? I do not need your help:

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: And God forbid a shallow scratch should drive

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: The Prince of Wales from such a field as this,

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: Where staind nobility lies trodden on,

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: and rebels arms triumph in massacres!

speaker: LANCASTER
text_entry: We breathe too long: come, cousin Westmoreland,

speaker: LANCASTER
text_entry: Our duty this way lies; for Gods sake come.

speaker: LANCASTER
text_entry: Exeunt LANCASTER and WESTMORELAND

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: By God, thou hast deceived me, Lancaster;

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: I did not think thee lord of such a spirit:

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: Before, I loved thee as a brother, John;

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: But now, I do respect thee as my soul.

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: I saw him hold Lord Percy at the point

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: With lustier maintenance than I did look for

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: Of such an ungrown warrior.

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: O, this boy

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: Lends mettle to us all!

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: Exit

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: Enter DOUGLAS

speaker: EARL OF DOUGLAS
text_entry: Another king! they grow like Hydras heads:

speaker: EARL OF DOUGLAS
text_entry: I am the Douglas, fatal to all those

speaker: EARL OF DOUGLAS
text_entry: That wear those colours on them: what art thou,

speaker: EARL OF DOUGLAS
text_entry: That counterfeitst the person of a king?

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: The king himself; who, Douglas, grieves at heart

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: So many of his shadows thou hast met

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: And not the very king. I have two boys

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: Seek Percy and thyself about the field:

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: But, seeing thou fallst on me so luckily,

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: I will assay thee: so, defend thyself.

speaker: EARL OF DOUGLAS
text_entry: I fear thou art another counterfeit;

speaker: EARL OF DOUGLAS
text_entry: And yet, in faith, thou bearst thee like a king:

speaker: EARL OF DOUGLAS
text_entry: But mine I am sure thou art, whoeer thou be,

speaker: EARL OF DOUGLAS
text_entry: And thus I win thee.

speaker: EARL OF DOUGLAS
text_entry: They fight. KING HENRY being in danger, PRINCE HENRY enters

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: Hold up thy head, vile Scot, or thou art like

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: Never to hold it up again! the spirits

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: Of valiant Shirley, Stafford, Blunt, are in my arms:

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: It is the Prince of Wales that threatens thee;

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: Who never promiseth but he means to pay.

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: They fight: DOUGLAS flies

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: Cheerly, my lordhow fares your grace?

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: Sir Nicholas Gawsey hath for succor sent,

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: And so hath Clifton: Ill to Clifton straight.

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: Stay, and breathe awhile:

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: Thou hast redeemd thy lost opinion,

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: And showd thou makest some tender of my life,

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: In this fair rescue thou hast brought to me.

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: O God! they did me too much injury

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: That ever said I hearkend for your death.

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: If it were so, I might have let alone

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: The insulting hand of Douglas over you,

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: Which would have been as speedy in your end

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: As all the poisonous potions in the world

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: And saved the treacherous labour of your son.

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: Make up to Clifton: Ill to Sir Nicholas Gawsey.

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: Exit

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: Enter HOTSPUR

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: If I mistake not, thou art Harry Monmouth.

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: Thou speakst as if I would deny my name.

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: My name is Harry Percy.

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: Why, then I see

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: A very valiant rebel of the name.

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: I am the Prince of Wales; and think not, Percy,

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: To share with me in glory any more:

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: Two stars keep not their motion in one sphere;

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: Nor can one England brook a double reign,

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: Of Harry Percy and the Prince of Wales.

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Nor shall it, Harry; for the hour is come

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: To end the one of us; and would to God

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Thy name in arms were now as great as mine!

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: Ill make it greater ere I part from thee;

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: And all the budding honours on thy crest

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: Ill crop, to make a garland for my head.

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: I can no longer brook thy vanities.

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: They fight

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Enter FALSTAFF

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: Well said, Hal! to it Hal! Nay, you shall find no

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: boys play here, I can tell you.

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: Re-enter DOUGLAS; he fights with FALSTAFF,  who falls down as if he were dead, and exit DOUGLAS. HOTSPUR is wounded, and falls

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: O, Harry, thou hast robbd me of my youth!

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: I better brook the loss of brittle life

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Than those proud titles thou hast won of me;

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: They wound my thoughts worse than sword my flesh:

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: But thoughts the slave of life, and life times fool;

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: And time, that takes survey of all the world,

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Must have a stop. O, I could prophesy,

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: But that the earthy and cold hand of death

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Lies on my tongue: no, Percy, thou art dust

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: And food for--

speaker: HOTSPUR
text_entry: Dies

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: For worms, brave Percy: fare thee well, great heart!

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: Ill-weaved ambition, how much art thou shrunk!

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: When that this body did contain a spirit,

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: A kingdom for it was too small a bound;

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: But now two paces of the vilest earth

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: Is room enough: this earth that bears thee dead

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: Bears not alive so stout a gentleman.

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: If thou wert sensible of courtesy,

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: I should not make so dear a show of zeal:

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: But let my favours hide thy mangled face;

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: And, even in thy behalf, Ill thank myself

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: For doing these fair rites of tenderness.

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: Adieu, and take thy praise with thee to heaven!

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: Thy ignominy sleep with thee in the grave,

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: But not rememberd in thy epitaph!

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: He spieth FALSTAFF on the ground

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: What, old acquaintance! could not all this flesh

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: Keep in a little life? Poor Jack, farewell!

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: I could have better spared a better man:

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: O, I should have a heavy miss of thee,

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: If I were much in love with vanity!

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: Death hath not struck so fat a deer to-day,

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: Though many dearer, in this bloody fray.

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: Embowelld will I see thee by and by:

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: Till then in blood by noble Percy lie.

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: Exit PRINCE HENRY

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: [Rising up]  Embowelled! if thou embowel me to-day,

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: Ill give you leave to powder me and eat me too

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: to-morrow. Sblood,twas time to counterfeit, or

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: that hot termagant Scot had paid me scot and lot too.

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: Counterfeit? I lie, I am no counterfeit: to die,

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: is to be a counterfeit; for he is but the

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: counterfeit of a man who hath not the life of a man:

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: but to counterfeit dying, when a man thereby

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: liveth, is to be no counterfeit, but the true and

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: perfect image of life indeed. The better part of

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: valour is discretion; in the which better part I

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: have saved my life.Zounds, I am afraid of this

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: gunpowder Percy, though he be dead: how, if he

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: should counterfeit too and rise? by my faith, I am

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: afraid he would prove the better counterfeit.

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: Therefore Ill make him sure; yea, and Ill swear I

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: killed him. Why may not he rise as well as I?

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: Nothing confutes me but eyes, and nobody sees me.

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: Therefore, sirrah,

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: Stabbing him

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: with a new wound in your thigh, come you along with me.

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: Takes up HOTSPUR on his back

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: Re-enter PRINCE HENRY and LORD JOHN OF LANCASTER

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: Come, brother John; full bravely hast thou fleshd

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: Thy maiden sword.

speaker: LANCASTER
text_entry: But, soft! whom have we here?

speaker: LANCASTER
text_entry: Did you not tell me this fat man was dead?

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: I did; I saw him dead,

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: Breathless and bleeding on the ground. Art

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: thou alive?

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: Or is it fantasy that plays upon our eyesight?

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: I prithee, speak; we will not trust our eyes

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: Without our ears: thou art not what thou seemst.

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: No, thats certain; I am not a double man: but if I

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: be not Jack Falstaff, then am I a Jack. There is Percy:

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: Throwing the body down

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: if your father will do me any honour, so; if not, let

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: him kill the next Percy himself. I look to be either

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: earl or duke, I can assure you.

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: Why, Percy I killed myself and saw thee dead.

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: Didst thou? Lord, Lord, how this world is given to

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: lying! I grant you I was down and out of breath;

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: and so was he: but we rose both at an instant and

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: fought a long hour by Shrewsbury clock. If I may be

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: believed, so; if not, let them that should reward

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: valour bear the sin upon their own heads. Ill take

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: it upon my death, I gave him this wound in the

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: thigh: if the man were alive and would deny it,

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: zounds, I would make him eat a piece of my sword.

speaker: LANCASTER
text_entry: This is the strangest tale that ever I heard.

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: This is the strangest fellow, brother John.

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: Come, bring your luggage nobly on your back:

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: For my part, if a lie may do thee grace,

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: Ill gild it with the happiest terms I have.

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: A retreat is sounded

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: The trumpet sounds retreat; the day is ours.

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: Come, brother, let us to the highest of the field,

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: To see what friends are living, who are dead.

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: Exeunt PRINCE HENRY and LANCASTER

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: Ill follow, as they say, for reward. He that

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: rewards me, God reward him! If I do grow great,

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: Ill grow less; for Ill purge, and leave sack, and

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: live cleanly as a nobleman should do.

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: Exit

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: SCENE V. Another part of the field.

speaker: FALSTAFF
text_entry: The trumpets sound. Enter KING HENRY IV, PRINCE  HENRY, LORD JOHN LANCASTER, EARL OF WESTMORELAND, with WORCESTER and VERNON prisoners

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: Thus ever did rebellion find rebuke.

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: Ill-spirited Worcester! did not we send grace,

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: Pardon and terms of love to all of you?

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: And wouldst thou turn our offers contrary?

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: Misuse the tenor of thy kinsmans trust?

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: Three knights upon our party slain to-day,

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: A noble earl and many a creature else

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: Had been alive this hour,

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: If like a Christian thou hadst truly borne

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: Betwixt our armies true intelligence.

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: What I have done my safety urged me to;

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: And I embrace this fortune patiently,

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER
text_entry: Since not to be avoided it falls on me.

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: Bear Worcester to the death and Vernon too:

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: Other offenders we will pause upon.

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: Exeunt WORCESTER and VERNON, guarded

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: How goes the field?

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: The noble Scot, Lord Douglas, when he saw

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: The fortune of the day quite turnd from him,

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: The noble Percy slain, and all his men

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: Upon the foot of fear, fled with the rest;

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: And falling from a hill, he was so bruised

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: That the pursuers took him. At my tent

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: The Douglas is; and I beseech your grace

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: I may dispose of him.

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: With all my heart.

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: Then, brother John of Lancaster, to you

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: This honourable bounty shall belong:

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: Go to the Douglas, and deliver him

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: Up to his pleasure, ransomless and free:

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: His valour shown upon our crests to-day

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: Hath taught us how to cherish such high deeds

speaker: PRINCE HENRY
text_entry: Even in the bosom of our adversaries.

speaker: LANCASTER
text_entry: I thank your grace for this high courtesy,

speaker: LANCASTER
text_entry: Which I shall give away immediately.

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: Then this remains, that we divide our power.

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: You, son John, and my cousin Westmoreland

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: Towards York shall bend you with your dearest speed,

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: To meet Northumberland and the prelate Scroop,

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: Who, as we hear, are busily in arms:

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: Myself and you, son Harry, will towards Wales,

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: To fight with Glendower and the Earl of March.

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: Rebellion in this land shall lose his sway,

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: Meeting the cheque of such another day:

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: And since this business so fair is done,

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: Let us not leave till all our own be won.

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: ACT I

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: SCENE I. Westminster Abbey.

speaker: KING HENRY IV
text_entry: Dead March. Enter the Funeral of KING HENRY the  Fifth, attended on by Dukes of BEDFORD, Regent of  France; GLOUCESTER, Protector; and EXETER, Earl of WARWICK, the BISHOP OF WINCHESTER, Heralds,  and c

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: Hung be the heavens with black, yield day to night!

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: Comets, importing change of times and states,

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: Brandish your crystal tresses in the sky,

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: And with them scourge the bad revolting stars

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: That have consented unto Henrys death!

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: King Henry the Fifth, too famous to live long!

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: England neer lost a king of so much worth.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: England neer had a king until his time.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Virtue he had, deserving to command:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: His brandishd sword did blind men with his beams:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: His arms spread wider than a dragons wings;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: His sparking eyes, replete with wrathful fire,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: More dazzled and drove back his enemies

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Than mid-day sun fierce bent against their faces.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: What should I say? his deeds exceed all speech:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: He neer lift up his hand but conquered.

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: We mourn in black: why mourn we not in blood?

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Henry is dead and never shall revive:

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Upon a wooden coffin we attend,

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: And deaths dishonourable victory

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: We with our stately presence glorify,

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Like captives bound to a triumphant car.

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: What! shall we curse the planets of mishap

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: That plotted thus our glorys overthrow?

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Or shall we think the subtle-witted French

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Conjurers and sorcerers, that afraid of him

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: By magic verses have contrived his end?

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: BISHOP

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: He was a king blessd of the King of kings.

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: Unto the French the dreadful judgement-day

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: So dreadful will not be as was his sight.

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: The battles of the Lord of hosts he fought:

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: The churchs prayers made him so prosperous.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: The church! where is it? Had not churchmen prayd,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: His thread of life had not so soon decayd:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: None do you like but an effeminate prince,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Whom, like a school-boy, you may over-awe.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: BISHOP

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: Gloucester, whateer we like, thou art protector

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: And lookest to command the prince and realm.

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: Thy wife is proud; she holdeth thee in awe,

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: More than God or religious churchmen may.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Name not religion, for thou lovest the flesh,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And neer throughout the year to church thou gost

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Except it be to pray against thy foes.

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: Cease, cease these jars and rest your minds in peace:

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: Lets to the altar: heralds, wait on us:

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: Instead of gold, well offer up our arms:

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: Since arms avail not now that Henrys dead.

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: Posterity, await for wretched years,

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: When at their mothers moist eyes babes shall suck,

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: Our isle be made a nourish of salt tears,

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: And none but women left to wail the dead.

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: Henry the Fifth, thy ghost I invocate:

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: Prosper this realm, keep it from civil broils,

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: Combat with adverse planets in the heavens!

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: A far more glorious star thy soul will make

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: Than Julius Caesar or bright--

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: Enter a Messenger

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: My honourable lords, health to you all!

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Sad tidings bring I to you out of France,

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Of loss, of slaughter and discomfiture:

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Guienne, Champagne, Rheims, Orleans,

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Paris, Guysors, Poictiers, are all quite lost.

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: What sayst thou, man, before dead Henrys corse?

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: Speak softly, or the loss of those great towns

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: Will make him burst his lead and rise from death.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Is Paris lost? is Rouen yielded up?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: If Henry were recalld to life again,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: These news would cause him once more yield the ghost.

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: How were they lost? what treachery was used?

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: No treachery; but want of men and money.

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Amongst the soldiers this is muttered,

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: That here you maintain several factions,

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: And whilst a field should be dispatchd and fought,

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: You are disputing of your generals:

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: One would have lingering wars with little cost;

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Another would fly swift, but wanteth wings;

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: A third thinks, without expense at all,

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: By guileful fair words peace may be obtaind.

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Awake, awake, English nobility!

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Let not sloth dim your horrors new-begot:

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Croppd are the flower-de-luces in your arms;

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Of Englands coat one half is cut away.

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Were our tears wanting to this funeral,

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: These tidings would call forth their flowing tides.

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: Me they concern; Regent I am of France.

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: Give me my steeled coat. Ill fight for France.

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: Away with these disgraceful wailing robes!

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: Wounds will I lend the French instead of eyes,

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: To weep their intermissive miseries.

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: Enter to them another Messenger

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Lords, view these letters full of bad mischance.

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: France is revolted from the English quite,

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Except some petty towns of no import:

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: The Dauphin Charles is crowned king of Rheims;

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: The Bastard of Orleans with him is joind;

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Reignier, Duke of Anjou, doth take his part;

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: The Duke of Alencon flieth to his side.

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: The Dauphin crowned king! all fly to him!

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: O, whither shall we fly from this reproach?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: We will not fly, but to our enemies throats.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Bedford, if thou be slack, Ill fight it out.

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: Gloucester, why doubtst thou of my forwardness?

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: An army have I musterd in my thoughts,

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: Wherewith already France is overrun.

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: Enter another Messenger

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: My gracious lords, to add to your laments,

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Wherewith you now bedew King Henrys hearse,

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: I must inform you of a dismal fight

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Betwixt the stout Lord Talbot and the French.

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: BISHOP

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: What! wherein Talbot overcame? ist so?

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: O, no; wherein Lord Talbot was oerthrown:

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: The circumstance Ill tell you more at large.

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: The tenth of August last this dreadful lord,

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Retiring from the siege of Orleans,

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Having full scarce six thousand in his troop.

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: By three and twenty thousand of the French

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Was round encompassed and set upon.

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: No leisure had he to enrank his men;

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: He wanted pikes to set before his archers;

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Instead whereof sharp stakes pluckd out of hedges

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: They pitched in the ground confusedly,

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: To keep the horsemen off from breaking in.

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: More than three hours the fight continued;

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Where valiant Talbot above human thought

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Enacted wonders with his sword and lance:

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Hundreds he sent to hell, and none durst stand him;

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Here, there, and every where, enraged he flew:

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: The French exclaimd, the devil was in arms;

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: All the whole army stood agazed on him:

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: His soldiers spying his undaunted spirit

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: A Talbot! a Talbot! cried out amain

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: And rushd into the bowels of the battle.

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Here had the conquest fully been seald up,

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: If Sir John Fastolfe had not playd the coward:

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: He, being in the vaward, placed behind

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: With purpose to relieve and follow them,

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Cowardly fled, not having struck one stroke.

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Hence grew the general wreck and massacre;

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Enclosed were they with their enemies:

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: A base Walloon, to win the Dauphins grace,

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Thrust Talbot with a spear into the back,

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Whom all France with their chief assembled strength

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Durst not presume to look once in the face.

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: Is Talbot slain? then I will slay myself,

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: For living idly here in pomp and ease,

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: Whilst such a worthy leader, wanting aid,

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: Unto his dastard foemen is betrayd.

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: O no, he lives; but is took prisoner,

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: And Lord Scales with him and Lord Hungerford:

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Most of the rest slaughterd or took likewise.

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: His ransom there is none but I shall pay:

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: Ill hale the Dauphin headlong from his throne:

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: His crown shall be the ransom of my friend;

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: Four of their lords Ill change for one of ours.

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: Farewell, my masters; to my task will I;

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: Bonfires in France forthwith I am to make,

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: To keep our great Saint Georges feast withal:

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: Ten thousand soldiers with me I will take,

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: Whose bloody deeds shall make all Europe quake.

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: So you had need; for Orleans is besieged;

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: The English army is grown weak and faint:

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: The Earl of Salisbury craveth supply,

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: And hardly keeps his men from mutiny,

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Since they, so few, watch such a multitude.

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Remember, lords, your oaths to Henry sworn,

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Either to quell the Dauphin utterly,

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Or bring him in obedience to your yoke.

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: I do remember it; and here take my leave,

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: To go about my preparation.

speaker: BEDFORD
text_entry: Exit

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Ill to the Tower with all the haste I can,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: To view the artillery and munition;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And then I will proclaim young Henry king.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Exit

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: To Eltham will I, where the young king is,

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Being ordaind his special governor,

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: And for his safety there Ill best devise.

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Exit

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: BISHOP

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: Each hath his place and function to attend:

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: I am left out; for me nothing remains.

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: But long I will not be Jack out of office:

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: The king from Eltham I intend to steal

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: And sit at chiefest stern of public weal.

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: SCENE II. France. Before Orleans.

speaker: OF WINCHESTER
text_entry: Sound a flourish. Enter CHARLES, ALENCON, and REIGNIER, marching with drum and Soldiers

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Mars his true moving, even as in the heavens

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: So in the earth, to this day is not known:

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Late did he shine upon the English side;

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Now we are victors; upon us he smiles.

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: What towns of any moment but we have?

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: At pleasure here we lie near Orleans;

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Otherwhiles the famishd English, like pale ghosts,

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Faintly besiege us one hour in a month.

speaker: ALENCON
text_entry: They want their porridge and their fat bull-beeves:

speaker: ALENCON
text_entry: Either they must be dieted like mules

speaker: ALENCON
text_entry: And have their provender tied to their mouths

speaker: ALENCON
text_entry: Or piteous they will look, like drowned mice.

speaker: REIGNIER
text_entry: Lets raise the siege: why live we idly here?

speaker: REIGNIER
text_entry: Talbot is taken, whom we wont to fear:

speaker: REIGNIER
text_entry: Remaineth none but mad-braind Salisbury;

speaker: REIGNIER
text_entry: And he may well in fretting spend his gall,

speaker: REIGNIER
text_entry: Nor men nor money hath he to make war.

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Sound, sound alarum! we will rush on them.

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Now for the honour of the forlorn French!

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Him I forgive my death that killeth me

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: When he sees me go back one foot or fly.

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Here alarum; they are beaten back by the English with great loss. Re-enter CHARLES, ALENCON, and REIGNIER

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Who ever saw the like? what men have I!

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Dogs! cowards! dastards! I would neer have fled,

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: But that they left me midst my enemies.

speaker: REIGNIER
text_entry: Salisbury is a desperate homicide;

speaker: REIGNIER
text_entry: He fighteth as one weary of his life.

speaker: REIGNIER
text_entry: The other lords, like lions wanting food,

speaker: REIGNIER
text_entry: Do rush upon us as their hungry prey.

speaker: ALENCON
text_entry: Froissart, a countryman of ours, records,

speaker: ALENCON
text_entry: England all Olivers and Rowlands bred,

speaker: ALENCON
text_entry: During the time Edward the Third did reign.

speaker: ALENCON
text_entry: More truly now may this be verified;

speaker: ALENCON
text_entry: For none but Samsons and Goliases

speaker: ALENCON
text_entry: It sendeth forth to skirmish. One to ten!

speaker: ALENCON
text_entry: Lean, raw-boned rascals! who would eer suppose

speaker: ALENCON
text_entry: They had such courage and audacity?

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Lets leave this town; for they are hare-braind slaves,

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: And hunger will enforce them to be more eager:

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Of old I know them; rather with their teeth

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: The walls theyll tear down than forsake the siege.

speaker: REIGNIER
text_entry: I think, by some odd gimmors or device

speaker: REIGNIER
text_entry: Their arms are set like clocks, stiff to strike on;

speaker: REIGNIER
text_entry: Else neer could they hold out so as they do.

speaker: REIGNIER
text_entry: By my consent, well even let them alone.

speaker: ALENCON
text_entry: Be it so.

speaker: ALENCON
text_entry: Enter the BASTARD OF ORLEANS

speaker: BASTARD OF ORLEANS
text_entry: Wheres the Prince Dauphin? I have news for him.

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Bastard of Orleans, thrice welcome to us.

speaker: BASTARD OF ORLEANS
text_entry: Methinks your looks are sad, your cheer appalld:

speaker: BASTARD OF ORLEANS
text_entry: Hath the late overthrow wrought this offence?

speaker: BASTARD OF ORLEANS
text_entry: Be not dismayd, for succor is at hand:

speaker: BASTARD OF ORLEANS
text_entry: A holy maid hither with me I bring,

speaker: BASTARD OF ORLEANS
text_entry: Which by a vision sent to her from heaven

speaker: BASTARD OF ORLEANS
text_entry: Ordained is to raise this tedious siege

speaker: BASTARD OF ORLEANS
text_entry: And drive the English forth the bounds of France.

speaker: BASTARD OF ORLEANS
text_entry: The spirit of deep prophecy she hath,

speaker: BASTARD OF ORLEANS
text_entry: Exceeding the nine sibyls of old Rome:

speaker: BASTARD OF ORLEANS
text_entry: Whats past and whats to come she can descry.

speaker: BASTARD OF ORLEANS
text_entry: Speak, shall I call her in? Believe my words,

speaker: BASTARD OF ORLEANS
text_entry: For they are certain and unfallible.

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Go, call her in.

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Exit BASTARD OF ORLEANS

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: But first, to try her skill,

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Reignier, stand thou as Dauphin in my place:

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Question her proudly; let thy looks be stern:

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: By this means shall we sound what skill she hath.

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Re-enter the BASTARD OF ORLEANS, with JOAN LA PUCELLE

speaker: REIGNIER
text_entry: Fair maid, ist thou wilt do these wondrous feats?

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Reignier, ist thou that thinkest to beguile me?

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Where is the Dauphin? Come, come from behind;

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: I know thee well, though never seen before.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Be not amazed, theres nothing hid from me:

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: In private will I talk with thee apart.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Stand back, you lords, and give us leave awhile.

speaker: REIGNIER
text_entry: She takes upon her bravely at first dash.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Dauphin, I am by birth a shepherds daughter,

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: My wit untraind in any kind of art.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Heaven and our Lady gracious hath it pleased

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: To shine on my contemptible estate:

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Lo, whilst I waited on my tender lambs,

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: And to suns parching heat displayd my cheeks,

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Gods mother deigned to appear to me

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: And in a vision full of majesty

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Willd me to leave my base vocation

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: And free my country from calamity:

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Her aid she promised and assured success:

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: In complete glory she reveald herself;

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: And, whereas I was black and swart before,

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: With those clear rays which she infused on me

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: That beauty am I blessd with which you see.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Ask me what question thou canst possible,

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: And I will answer unpremeditated:

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: My courage try by combat, if thou darest,

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: And thou shalt find that I exceed my sex.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Resolve on this, thou shalt be fortunate,

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: If thou receive me for thy warlike mate.

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Thou hast astonishd me with thy high terms:

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Only this proof Ill of thy valour make,

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: In single combat thou shalt buckle with me,

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: And if thou vanquishest, thy words are true;

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Otherwise I renounce all confidence.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: I am prepared: here is my keen-edged sword,

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Deckd with five flower-de-luces on each side;

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: The which at Touraine, in Saint Katharines

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: churchyard,

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Out of a great deal of old iron I chose forth.

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Then come, o Gods name; I fear no woman.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: And while I live, Ill neer fly from a man.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Here they fight, and JOAN LA PUCELLE overcomes

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Stay, stay thy hands! thou art an Amazon

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: And fightest with the sword of Deborah.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Christs mother helps me, else I were too weak.

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Whoeer helps thee, tis thou that must help me:

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Impatiently I burn with thy desire;

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: My heart and hands thou hast at once subdued.

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Excellent Pucelle, if thy name be so,

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Let me thy servant and not sovereign be:

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Tis the French Dauphin sueth to thee thus.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: I must not yield to any rites of love,

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: For my professions sacred from above:

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: When I have chased all thy foes from hence,

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Then will I think upon a recompense.

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Meantime look gracious on thy prostrate thrall.

speaker: REIGNIER
text_entry: My lord, methinks, is very long in talk.

speaker: ALENCON
text_entry: Doubtless he shrives this woman to her smock;

speaker: ALENCON
text_entry: Else neer could he so long protract his speech.

speaker: REIGNIER
text_entry: Shall we disturb him, since he keeps no mean?

speaker: ALENCON
text_entry: He may mean more than we poor men do know:

speaker: ALENCON
text_entry: These women are shrewd tempters with their tongues.

speaker: REIGNIER
text_entry: My lord, where are you? what devise you on?

speaker: REIGNIER
text_entry: Shall we give over Orleans, or no?

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Why, no, I say, distrustful recreants!

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Fight till the last gasp; I will be your guard.

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: What she says Ill confirm: well fight it out.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Assignd am I to be the English scourge.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: This night the siege assuredly Ill raise:

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Expect Saint Martins summer, halcyon days,

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Since I have entered into these wars.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Glory is like a circle in the water,

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Which never ceaseth to enlarge itself

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Till by broad spreading it disperse to nought.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: With Henrys death the English circle ends;

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Dispersed are the glories it included.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Now am I like that proud insulting ship

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Which Caesar and his fortune bare at once.

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Was Mahomet inspired with a dove?

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Thou with an eagle art inspired then.

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Helen, the mother of great Constantine,

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Nor yet Saint Philips daughters, were like thee.

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Bright star of Venus, falln down on the earth,

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: How may I reverently worship thee enough?

speaker: ALENCON
text_entry: Leave off delays, and let us raise the siege.

speaker: REIGNIER
text_entry: Woman, do what thou canst to save our honours;

speaker: REIGNIER
text_entry: Drive them from Orleans and be immortalized.

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Presently well try: come, lets away about it:

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: No prophet will I trust, if she prove false.

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: SCENE III. London. Before the Tower.

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Enter GLOUCESTER, with his Serving-men in blue coats

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: I am come to survey the Tower this day:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Since Henrys death, I fear, there is conveyance.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Where be these warders, that they wait not here?
